This is a hands-on workshop consisting of five modules, covering the entire process of creating an R package: functions and data, checking and testing, all levels of documentation, publication and maintenance.

title: Packaging dataPublication and maintenance
text:
Including data
There are 3 types of data we might want to include:

Exported data for the user to access: put in /data
Internal data for functions to access: put in /R/sysdata.rda
Raw data: put in /inst/extdata

title: Packaging dataPublication and maintenance
text:
Exported data
The data should be saved in /data as an .rda (or .RData) file.
usethis::use_data() will do this for you, as well as a few other necessary steps:

letter_indices <- data.frame(letter = letters, index = seq_along(letters))
usethis::use_data(letter_indices)

‚úî Adding 'R' to Depends field in DESCRIPTION
‚úî Creating 'data/'
‚úî Setting LazyData to 'true' in 'DESCRIPTION'
‚úî Saving 'letter_indices' to 'data/letter_indices.rda'
‚Ä¢ Document your data (see 'https://r-pkgs.org/data.html')







Note


For larger datasets, you can try changing the compress argument to get the best compression.

title: Packaging dataPublication and maintenance
text:
Provenance
Often the data that you want to make accessible to the users is one you have created with an R script ‚Äì either from scratch or from a raw data set.
It‚Äôs a good idea to put the R script and any corresponding raw data in /data-raw.
usethis::use_data_raw("dataname") will set this up:

Create /data-raw
Add /data-raw/dataname.R for you to add the code needed to create the data
Add ^data-raw$ to .Rbuildignore as it does not need to be included in the actual package.

You should add any raw data files (e.g.¬†.csv files) to /data-raw.

title: Packaging dataPublication and maintenance
text:
Documenting Data
Datasets in /data are always exported, so must be documented.
To document a dataset, we must have an .R script in /R that contains a Roxygen block above the name of the dataset.
As with functions, you can choose how to arrange this, e.g.¬†in one combined /R/data.R or in a separate R file for each dataset.

title: Packaging dataPublication and maintenance
Packaging dataPublication and maintenance
text:
Data source
For collected data, the (original) source should be documented with #' @source.
This should either be a url, e.g.

#' @source \url{http://www.diamondse.info/}

(alternatively \href{DiamondSearchEngine}{http://www.diamondse.info/}), or a reference, e.g.

#' @source Henderson and Velleman (1981), Building multiple  
#' #' regression models interactively. *Biometrics*, **37**, 391‚Äì411.

title: Packaging dataPublication and maintenance
text:
Internal data
Sometimes functions need access to reference data, e.g.¬†constants or look-up tables, that don‚Äôt need to be shared with users.
These objects should be saved in a single R/sysdata.rda file.
This can be done with use_data(..., internal = TRUE), e.g.

x <- sample(1000)
usethis::use_data(x, mtcars, internal = TRUE)

The generating code and any raw data can be put in /data-raw.
As the objects are not exported, they don‚Äôt need to be documented.

title: Packaging dataPublication and maintenance
text:
Raw data
Sometimes you want to include raw data, to use in examples or vignettes.
These files can be any format and should be added directly into /inst/extdata.
When the package is installed, these files will be copied to the extdata directory and their path on your system can be found as follows:

system.file("extdata", "mtcars.csv", package = "readr")

[1] "/Users/u2175871/Library/R/arm64/4.5/library/readr/extdata/mtcars.csv"

section: Your package is already on GitHub
text:
Your package is already on GitHub
Since your package is already on GitHub, any R user can install it with
remotes::install_github("USER/REPO")
If you want to tag it as a release, make sure there‚Äôs a NEWS.md file then run
usethis::use_version() # set the release version number
Check the NEWS.md file is up-to-date (use_version() will modify it) then
usethis::use_github_release()
This will bundle the source code as a zip and a tar.gz and make them available from the Releases section of the repo homepage.

See previous session for details about NEWS.md and usethis::use_news_md()
use_github_release() is also part of the CRAN submission process, towards the end of the use_release_issue() to-do list.

R-Universe
With R-Universe, you can create a personal, CRAN-like repository.
You‚Äôre in control of what‚Äôs published in your R-Universe!
It is a good way to allow users to easily install packages without going through the rigour of the CRAN submission process.
Useful resources:

Search the whole R-universe: https://r-universe.dev/search/
About the R-universe: https://ropensci.org/r-universe/
R-universe help-page: https://github.com/r-universe-org/help


A project from rOpenSci

section: Installing a package from an R-universe
text:
Installing a package from an R-universe
Binaries are built for Windows and MacOS, which a user can install using install.packages(), e.g.

# Install 'warwickplots' from the 'warwick-stats-resources' universe
install.packages('warwickplots', repos = c(
  WSR = 'https://warwick-stats-resources.r-universe.dev',
  CRAN = 'https://cloud.r-project.org')
)


Alternatively, you can first set options(repos) to enable favourite repositories by default:

options(repos = c(
  WSR = 'https://warwick-stats-resources.r-universe.dev',
  CRAN = 'https://cloud.r-project.org')
)
install.packages("warwickplots")


Give an aside about the warwickplots package
Note that we need to list CRAN as r-universe packages may have dependencies on CRAN packages.
To make options persist across sessions, add this code to your .RProfile with usethis::edit_r_profile()
CRAN repo is listed because r-universe package may have dependencies on packages on CRAN.

title: Packaging dataPublication and maintenance
text:
Create your R-universe
Follow this rOpenSci guide: How to create your personal CRAN-like repository on R-universe.

In a nutshell:

Create a repository called <username>.r-universe.dev on the GitHub account for username, e.g.¬†https://github.com/maelle/maelle.r-universe.dev. The repository must contain a file called packages.json in the standard format, defining at least the package name and git url for the packages you want to include, e.g.
[
    {
        "package": "warwickplots",
        "url": "https://github.com/Warwick-Stats-Resources/warwickplots"
    }
]
Install the r-universe app on the GitHub account that you want to enable. Choose enable for all repositories when asked.



Still using maelle in places as shorter that Warwick-Stats-Resources! Also, nice to give a shout-out to her and her role in rOpenSci.
Copying the example from the r-universe help page, with the example/links to Maelle, but using the example json from WSR to be consistent with previous slide.
Might be worth pointing out that with actual username, don‚Äôt need < >

title: Packaging dataPublication and maintenance
text:
What happens next

After a few minutes, your source universe will appear on: https://github.com/r-universe/<username>
The universe automatically starts building the packages from your registry. Once finished, they will appear on https://<username>.r-universe.dev
The universe automatically syncs and builds your package git repos once per hour.
If you encounter any issues, the actions tab in your source universe may show what is going on, for example: https://github.com/r-universe/maelle/actions

title: Packaging dataPublication and maintenance
text:
usethis::use_release_issue()
This function will first ask you to select the release version (major, minor, patch) then create and open a to-do list as an issue in the package GitHub repo.
For a first submission, there are around 22 tasks to complete, split into sections, to follow (more-or-less) in order:

First release (one-time only)
Prepare for release
Submit to CRAN
Wait for CRAN (things to do after package has been accepted)

For more details on each, see the Releasing to CRAN chapter of the R Packages book.

Number of tasks may vary depending on what you‚Äôve already done (e.g.¬†use_news_md will appear on list if you haven‚Äôt already got a NEWS.md file, but won‚Äôt if you do.)
Some are clearly optional (e.g.¬†drafting a blog post about the release) but most should be followed.
Some relate to promoting the package, rather than the technicalities of releasing it.
There are some different items for packages already on CRAN - not covered here - see Release chapter of R Packages for more details
Will catch many common ‚Äògotchas‚Äô, e.g.¬†Title Case for Title, checking all exported functions have @returns and @examples

title: Packaging dataPublication and maintenance
text:
Run ‚Äúas CRAN‚Äù checks
CRAN policies state that you must run R CMD check --as-cran on the tarball to be uploaded with the current version of R-devel.
First make sure the package passes check locally:
devtools::check()
Then allow some extra checks:
devtools::check(remote = TRUE, manual = TRUE)
Then send to CRAN‚Äôs win-builder to check on R-devel
devtools::check_win_devel()
Also check on Mac (M1)
devtools::check_mac_release()

It‚Äôs possible that the way your libraries are set up can mask problems with check() on your local machine. For example, it‚Äôs important that your System Library just comes with base and recommended packages and that all packages that you install go in your user library. Aside: Installing R through rig takes care of this for you.

R-hub v2

A new (since April 2024) check system.
Works best if the package is on GitHub
Works with GitHub Actions


# run once
install.packages(rhub) 
rhub::rhub_setup() # guides through set-up process
rhub::rhub_doctor() # checks the set-up

The use_release_issue() function uses devtools::submit_cran() rather than devtools::release(), but the documentation page for submit_cran() recommends using release() instead as it performs more checks.

If it‚Äôs from the CRAN robot, just fix the problem & resubmit.
If it‚Äôs from a human, do not respond to the email and do not argue. Instead update cran-comments.md & resubmit.

title: Function documentation and dependencies
text:
roxygen2
The roxygen2 package generates documentation from specially formatted comments, that we write above the function code, e.g.

#' @param x A numeric vector.


#' is a roxygen comment.
@param is a roxygen tag.
The @param tag takes an argument: the name of the parameter
The remaining text (until the next tag in the file) is the documentation relevant to the tag.

title: Function documentation and dependencies
text:
Common tags
There are four tags you‚Äôll use for most functions:




Tag
Purpose




@param arg
Describe inputs


@examples
Show how the function works


@return
Describe the return value (not needed if NULL)


@export
Add this tag if the function should be user-visible



 Usual RStudio shortcuts work in the @examples section, allowing you to run code interactively.

Other important ones: @seealso | Pointers to related functions @references @importFRom @method @note @rdname @keywords internal @format (data) @section

title: Function documentation and dependencies
text:
The description block
The roxygen comment should start with a description block.

First sentence is the title.
Next paragraph is the description.
Everything else is the details (optional).

#' Title in Title Case of up to 65 Characters
#'
#' Mandatory description of what the function does. 
#' Should be a short paragraph of a few lines only.
#'
#' The details section is optional and may be several paragraphs. It can even
#' contain sub-sections (not illustrated here).

title: Function documentation and dependencies
text:
RStudio helps you get started
Put your cursor inside a function, then select ‚ÄòInsert Roxygen Skeleton‚Äô from the Code menu.





#' Title
#'
#' @param animal
#' @param sound
#'
#' @return
#' @export
#'
#' @examples
animal_sounds <- function(animal, sound) {
  stopifnot(is.character(animal) & length(animal) == 1)
  stopifnot(is.character(sound) & length(sound) == 1)
  paste0("The ", animal, " goes ", sound, "!")
}

title: Function documentation and dependencies
text:
Default NAMESPACE

It is best to export functions explicitly
The NAMESPACE file as created by usethis::create_package() does not export anything by default.








Warning


A package created from the RStudio menus via File > New Project > New Directory > R Package creates a NAMESPACE that exports everything by default, with exportPattern("^[[:alpha:]]+")
This is a good reason not to do this: always call usethis::create_package() to create a package.
For similar reasons, also avoid package.skeleton().

title: Function documentation and dependencies

text:
What to export
Only export functions that you want your package users to use, i.e.¬†those that are relevant to the purpose of the package.
Don‚Äôt export internal helpers, e.g.
# Defaults for NULL values
`%||%` <- function(a, b) if (is.null(a)) b else a

# Remove NULLs from a list
compact <- function(x) {
  x[!vapply(x, is.null, logical(1))]
}







Note


Using the ‚ÄòInsert Roxygen Skeleton‚Äô option adds an @export tag.

Using markdown
Most commonly used mark-up is easier with markdown (and can be mixed with .Rd mark-up).

Text formatting: **bold**, _italic_, `code`
Create links

To a function in the same package: [func()]

R CMD check
R CMD check is the command line utility provided by R to check R packages.
It checks that all the components are valid and consistent with each other, in particular:

Metadata in DESCRIPTION

Authors@R: A call to person() that is run to create the Author field when the package tarball is built. ‚Äúaut‚Äù means author, ‚Äúcre‚Äù means creator (maintainer), ‚Äúctb‚Äù means contributor.
A placeholder call to person() is inserted in DESCRIPTION when a package is created with usethis::create_package() which can be edited directly:

GitHub Actions (GHAs) allow you to run code every time you push to GitHub.
The most useful ones for packages can be selected from a call to usethis::use_github_action():

Which action do you want to add? (0 to exit)

From the root of a package project:
usethis::use_testthat()
‚úî Adding 'testthat' to Suggests field in DESCRIPTION

title: Testing
section: Tests are organised in three layers
text:
Tests are organised in three layers


A file holds multiple related tests.
A test groups together multiple expectations to test the output from a simple function, a range of possibilities for a single parameter from a more complicated function, or tightly related functionality from across multiple functions.
An expectation is the atom of testing. It describes the expected result of a computation: Does it have the right value and right class?

title: Testing
text:
What to test
Test every individual task the function completes separately.
Check both for successful situations and for expected failure situations.

title: Testing
text:
Expectations
Three expectations cover the vast majority of cases
expect_equal(object, expected)

expect_error(object, regexp = NULL, class = NULL)

expect_warning(object, regexp = NULL, class = NULL)

It used to be standard practice to test for errors and warnings using regexp, but that has downsides - it‚Äôs not always clear why a test is failing. Testing via class is a more modern, safer approach, which we‚Äôll use below.

title: Testing

text:
Creating test files
First, create a test file for this function, in either way:
# In RStudio, with `animal_sounds.R` the active file:
usethis::use_test()  

# More generally
usethis::use_test("animal_sounds")







Note


RStudio makes it really easy to swap between associated R scripts and tests.
If the R file is open, usethis::use_test() (with no arguments) opens or creates the test.
With the test file open, usethis::use_r() (with no arguments) opens or creates the R script.

title: Testing
text:
Anatomy of a test

test_that(desc, code)


desc is the test name. Should be brief and evocative, e.g.¬†test_that("multiplication works", { ... }).
code is test code containing expectations. Braces ({}) should always be used in order to get accurate location data for test failures.

can include several expectations, as well as other code to help define them

  expect_equal(animal_sounds("cat", "miaow"), "The cat goes miaow!")
})

Run tests
Tests can be run interactively like any other R code. The output will appear in the console, e.g.¬†for a successful test:
Test passed üòÄ
Alternatively, we can run tests in the background with the output appearing in the build pane.

testthat::test_file() ‚Äì run all tests in a file (‚ÄòRun Tests‚Äô button)
devtools::test() ‚Äì run all tests in a package (Ctrl/Cmd + Shift + T, or Build > Test Package)

title: Testing
text:
Testing equality
For numeric values, expect_equal() allows some tolerance:

expect_equal(10, 10 + 1e-7)


expect_equal(10, 10 + 1e-4, tolerance = 1e-4)


expect_equal(10, 10 + 1e-5)

Error: 10 not equal to 10 + 1e-05.
1/1 mismatches
[1] 10 - 10 == -1e-05


Note that when the expectation is met, there is nothing printed.

Use expect_identical() to test exact equivalence.
Use expect_equal(ignore_attr = TRUE) to ignore different attributes (e.g.¬†names).

title: Testing
text:
expect_error(), expect_warning()
When we expect an error/warning when the code is run, we need to pass the call to expect_error()/expect_warning() directly.
One way is to expect a text outcome using a regular expression:

test_that("handles invalid inputs", {
    expect_error(animal_sounds("dog", c("woof", "bow wow wow")), 
                 "`sound` must be a single string")
})

However, the regexp can get fiddly, especially if there are characters to escape. There is a more modern, precise way‚Ä¶

have to call animal_sounds within expect_error - if we try calling it first (as we did in expect_equal) our code will throw an error before it has a chance to test for it!

title: Testing
text:
Using a condition class
When using cli::cli_abort() and cli::cli_warn() to throw errors and warnings, we can signal the condition with a class, which we can then use in our tests.
First, we need to modify the calls to cli::cli_abort in animal_sounds()

if (!rlang::is_character(sound, 1)) {
  cli::cli_abort(
    c("{.var sound} must be a single string!",
      "i" = "It was {.type {sound}} of length {length(sound)} instead."),
    class = "error_not_single_string"
  )
}

# and same for `animal` argument

title: Testing
section: Using a condition‚Äôs class in tests
text:
Using a condition‚Äôs class in tests
We can then check for this class in the test

test_that("handles invalid inputs", {
    expect_error(animal_sounds("dog", c("woof", "bow wow wow")), 
                 class = "error_not_single_string") 
})

Advantages of using class:

It is under your control
If the condition originates from base R or another package, proceed with caution ‚Äì a good reminder to re-consider the wisdom of testing a condition that is not fully under your control in the first place.

From https://r-pkgs.org/testing-basics.html#testing-errors

Need to use argument name class as not matched by position (regexp comes before first)

title: Testing
text:
Snapshot tests
Sometimes it is difficult to define the expected output, e.g.¬†to test images or output printed to the console. expect_snapshot() captures all messages, warnings, errors, and output from code.
When we expect the code to throw an error (e.g.¬†if we want to test the appearance of an informative message), we need to specify error = TRUE.

test_that("error message for invalid input", {
  expect_snapshot(animal_sounds("dog", c("woof", "bow wow wow")),
                  error = TRUE)
})

Snapshot tests can not be run interactively by sending to the console, instead we must use devtools::test() or testthat::testfile().

Prior knowledge
We do not assume any prior knowledge of R pacakge development, but basic knowledge of R is expected. In particular, participants should be confident writing functions. Some experience with RStudio is beneficial.

We also strongly recommend all participants to install the development tools to avoid potential issues installing packages.

Installing R
Download the pre-compiled binary for your OS from https://cloud.r-project.org/ and install. More specifically:
For Windows

For Linux
